Title: “Radical by necessity, not by choice”: From microaggressions to social activism
Abstract: © 2019 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.This chapter examines the microaggressions literature with the own scholarship on how structural violence moves under the skin of young people and transforms into social action. It draws not only from microaggression theory but also from broader frameworks of minority stress theory and studies on everyday discrimination. The chapter provides a framework developed by Michelle Fine and J. Ruglis that calls for interrogating “circuits of dispossession and resistance”. It illustrates how structures and histories of oppressionaffect groupsof young people; how dispossession in one arena bleeds into other arenas; and how resistance can be mobilized not only within groups but also across groups in solidarity. Queer and trans youth, particularly Youth of Color, report cumulative experiences of state violence, social discrimination, and intimate/stranger microaggressions. They also narrate individual and collective insistence on radical recognition and intersectionality, and they model stunning “conversion” struggles as they morph oppression into varied forms of activism.
